BioShock Infinite, the third game in the BioShock series, is, simply put, one of the best games I have ever played. Across four playthroughs on two platforms it has simply managed to blow my mind upon every time I boot it up. It isn't perfect, and it won't be for everyone, but my god do yourself a favor and give it a try.

[b] TL;DR at bottom! [/b]

[h1] Artstyle / design [/h1]

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1360717716]Screenshot 1[/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1362719304]Screenshot 2[/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1360717817]Screenshot 3[/url]

(All screenshots spoiler free)

BioShock Infinite was stunningly gorgeous when it launched in 2013. The blend of realism and animated/cartoon styles allowed this game to remain aesthetically pleasing and downright beautiful, even in 2018. Environments are colorful and fun to explore, (most) character models hold up well, and the weapon models are intricate, yet simplistic in design. Let the screenshots speak for themselves! :)

[h1]Environments[/h1]

The world of Columbia is entirely engrossing and fun. In comparison to Infinite's predecessors, the city is much more vast, allowing for engaging, face paced, chaotic gunplay. The environmental storytelling in this game is phenomenal. No matter if you're eavesdropping on a conversation near you or reading an advertisement from a local shop, this game is always conveying some sort of message to you whether it's relating to the overarching story or a local side story. Also, it's a flying city! C'mon, what's not to like?!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The game consists of three main gunplay elements: guns, vigors, and tears. All of these elements feels smooth and refined. Each of the numerous guns feel as if they have their own purpose and are best in their own situation. Vigors, on the other hand (pun intended), are more versatile and reusable (not to mention how badass they are...). However, what really makes the gunplay for me are the tears. These tears (basically portals) allow each playthrough to feel much more unique from any other, whether it be your own or a friends. This greatly adds to the replayability. When not fighting, you can scavange for supplies and money, as well as recordings called voxaphones (more on them later). However, towards the latter half of the game, gunplay starts to feel rather repetitive, if not entirely dull. There are some other minor issues as well, such as the playable character getting caught on terrain sometimes.

[h1]Story[/h1]

If you've heard someone talk about BioShock Infinite, it was most likely in regards to the story. And let me say, holy shit. This story is THE most engrossing story in a game I have ever played. Following suit to Bioshock 1 and 2, most of the game is told through voxaphones. As you collect and play them, small pieces of this mad jigzaw puzzle of a story start to come together, and you start to make connections in your head. Go into this story blind if possible, it deserves to be learned by the player without guides.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
 [*]The most engrossing story. Ever.
 [*]Tight gunplay and exploration
 [*]Beautiful environments
 [*]Colorful, fun artstyle
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
 [*]Weaker latter half
 [*]Small terrain hangups, can be annoying
 [*]Some characters look goofy
[/list]

Please. Play. This. Game. ASAP.

I managed to play this five years after release date without any spoilers and I would have been very impressed had it been released in 2018. It's not perfect. The combat gets clunky at times and the quests and story feel stretched for time in the end.  These complaints do not overshadow a fantastic experience. While I can mention only a few negatives, the postives are too numerous to list. This is one of the best games I've ever played. Factor in some sort of sale (I bought the series for $10) and this is a no-brainer must buy, must play.

Personally, it just brought too much away from the game. The gunplay just didn't seem right, I didn't like the fact that I was literally being held throughout the entire time. It was too linear. With 1 and 2, there was a linear path, but there was so many ways to branch off and do your own thing. This was just going mainstream and giving no options like this.

Big Daddies, Big Sisters, and Alpha Series were so much fun to fight. Patriots and Firemen were pretty underwhelming, and Handymen were pretty much OP unless you had that footwear item. 2 weapons was such a bad idea, since you had to restrict yourself to those weapons and figure out how you're gonna take enemies down, whereas in the previous 2, you can plan out enemies a lot better.

Picking your fights was always a fun thing in Bioshock 1 and Bioshock 2. Maybe you had low HP or EVE and didn't want to engage any enemies. You could sneak around and ensure that you could get more of an item before engaging. This was such a big thing with Big Daddies. You were never forced to kill them unless it was a tutorial section. Deciding which fights you wanted was such a fun concept. Here, it's just throwing enemies at you over and over.

The Plasmids, otherwise known as Vigors (Not such a memorable name, had to look up what they're called), aren't useful except for very niche situations. I was playing the games over the past month of March, finishing all 3, and I didn't buy a single Vigor upgrade from the Vendors. It kinda got to the same degree with my weapons. I kept the same 2 weapons throughout the entire game - The Handcannon and the Sniper. I only upgraded those 2. 5000 dosh by the end of the game. Speaking of the end of the game...

The Hand of the Prophet is one of the worst ways they could've handled the finale. Tower Defense isn't fun in most FPS games. What happened here just felt like stretching the game out longer than it needed to. We killed Comstock, we get the help of Songbird, defend the generator, and then FUCKING RAPTURE.

When playing through the game, I always knew that they wanted to link the game to Rapture somehow, but then they just straight up send you there through a tear, which felt wrong. The game should've been in Rapture the entire time. The ending, which was just more wrong, throws Rapture under the bus entirely.

I can't explain anymore than I can. Infinite just doesn't feel like a Bioshock game in my opinion.

[h1] Эйнштейт, Хоккинг, Нолан, Кодзима - что объединяет всех этих людей? Их принято называть гениями своего дела, но никто из них не настолько гениален, как Кен Левин, главный геймдизайнер всей серии Bioshock, а так же вся студия в целом. [/h1]
 Сразу прошу извинения, но я не сумел пройти первые две части Bioshock,потому что только я хотел их купить, как у них вышли наладом дышащие ремастеры, но ятак понял, что по хронологии [spoiler] (хотя о какой хронологии может идти речь, если в конце игры Элизабет вертит пространственно-временной континуум во все стороны подряд!) [/spoiler] эта часть идёт первой.
 Описать эту игру довольно прорсто: представьте себе Half-Life 2 в начале ХХ века, в котором Гордон бы умел говорить, Алекс открывать порталы в другие миры [spoiler] + оказывалась дочерью Гордона [/spoiler], а Уоллес Бринн в конце оказывался [spoiler] поседевшим Фрименом из другого мира [/spoiler], потому что Bioshock Infinite в 2013 (да и до сих пор) ощущается столь же большим прорывом в жанре стрелялок от первого лица, каким ощущался Half-Life в 98-м, а ведь до 2013 мир увидел такие замечательные игры, как [b] Bioshock 1 [/b] и [b] 2[/b], [b] Deus Ex: Human Revolution [/b] и [b] Dishonored [/b]!
Так что же в этой игре такого, что выделяет её на фоне остальных FPS-Action-RPG:
[list]
[*] Шедевральный дизайн уровней, лучше которого я не встречал ни в одном другом шутере, но это черта всей серии.
[*] Оригинальная стилистика ретро-футуризма: город в облаках,  наполненный золотыми статуями, летающими лодками, дирижаблями, грамофонами, радующими вас прекрасными мелодиями, аниматрониками-пропагандистами, аниматрониками-торговцами и наивными, незнающими о скелетах в шкафу,имякоторому город Колумбия!
[*] Глубокомысленнейший сюжет, которому и Ведьмаки не ровня.
[*] 8 различных прокачиваемых соляных способностей, обеспечивающие нелинейное и тактичное, но ни на секунду не проседающее в динамичности прохождение.
[*] Огромный (хотя до серии Borderlands ему так же далеко, как Андромеде до Mass Effect'a) арсенал стильного, разнообразного, опять же прокачиваемого оружия, каждое из которых эффективно в определённых ситуациях: у вас не получится комфортно пройти игру, держа в руках одну пушку.
[*] Воздушные американские горки. Я на первых из них 1.5 часа катался.
[*] Интерактивное окружение и секретные локации
[*] [i][b] ЭЛИЗАБЕТ [/i][/b]. Если вас на протяжении многих игр бесили бесполезные, мешающие пройти. нарывающиеся на вражеские пули/удары напарники, из-за которых вы не раз проваливали задания, то [i][b] ЭЛИЗАБЕТ [/i][/b] - совершенно обратный случай. Она будет помогать вам, доставая боеприпасы, соли и другие полезные ресурсы. Без неё вы наоборот не справитесь почти ни в одной ситуации. Она спасёт вас,когда вы при смерти, она поможет вам, если вы заблудились, однако она изредка грешит ролью дамы в беде которую Букер должен спасать. [spoiler] Если вы делали какие-то неприличные вещи с ней за Букера, вы [h1]ООООООООООООООЧЕНЬ об этом пожалеете [/h1] в конце игры [/spoiler]
[*] Местный раздвоенный J-Man
[*] Лучшие среди всех шутеров, что я видел пролог и концовка,делящая посмотревших её на 2 лагеря: 1) «ЧТО ЭТО ЗА Х***НЯ ТОЛЬКО ЧТО ПРОИЗОШЛА?!» и 2) «О боже! Это гениально! Оскара! Оскара в студию! Что?! Вы уже отдали его Кодзиме? А ну живо отберите его и передайте Оскар Кену Левину! Кодзиме до него, как Sea of Thieves до полноценной игры!» (быть может, что единственный представитель второго лагеря — я, но это не отменяет его наличие!)
А что же в этой игре вообще есть плохого: я обнаружил там лишь один минус: это битва с призраками на самом высоком уровне сложности, потому, что в них чересчур много патронов уходит на каждого противника, учитывая, что в таких битвах противников целый легион.
В итоге Bioshock Infinite это не просто стрелялка с людьми в старинных мундирах, а лучший шутер, что мне когда-либо приходилось видеть! До этого я всегда считал таковым Half-Life 2, но эта игра превосходит его чуть ли не по всем параметрам!

Великолепная игра , стоящая своих денег. 

Однако некоторые люди , вроде меня , будут сильно подавлены концовкой. Никода ещё не игра не оставляла меня таким эмоционально разбитым и подавленым , даже Deus Ex такого не смог.

Среди плюсов : 

1. Элизабет. Она не какой-нибудь компаньон , как я думал по-началу , она настоящая личность. Она кажется живой , особенно в первой половине игры. Ей нравится все исследовать и изучать в первый раз , а за этим очень интересно наблюдать.
2. Сюжет. Не знаю , из-за чего другие купили игру , но лично я купил её из-за сюжета и мне он даже очень сильно понравился ( bioshock всё-таки ).
3. ИИ. Не скажу , что ИИ хорошо проработан , но значительно лучше других игр 2013 ( если конечно игру не шибко обновляли в этом плане).
4. Атомосфера. Атмосфера просто великолепна , но Метро не переплюнет.
5. Графика. Графика , она очень приятная , простая , однотонная и в глаз ничего не бросается.

Минусы : 
1. Нет русской озвучки.
2. Bioshock Infinite является шутером относительно лёгким и посредственным , получить наслаждение от перестрелок в большинстве случаев не получится. 

Также хотелось бы отметить маленький потенциал для стелса , который , однако , не был использован ( хотя может это и к лучшему ).

Начав перепроходить Инфинит практически сразу после перепрохождения предыдущих двух частей, я таки окончательно убедился, что он - самая унылая и самая переоцененная часть серии. Превартить атмосферный иммерсив сим с возможностью экслоринга больших нелинейных локаций в рельсовый шутан средней паршивости - это, конечно, очень гениально.  Нет, под пивас с кальмарами третьий Биошок сойдет, но не этого ждешь от продолжения такой серии.  
Я искренне не понимаю почему все так наяривают  именно на Инфинит. Довольно топорный сюжет с параллельными мирами и путешествиями во времени удивит разве что человека, совсем не интересующегося научной фантастикой и никогда не слышавшего про этих наших Хайнлайнов, Азимовых и прочих Лемов. Персонажи? Так у нас тут всё повествование вертится вокруг Сьюхи мультивселенского масштаба. Геймплей? Да, он стал  в целом подинамичнее, перестрелок в сравнении  с предыдущими частями стало больше, но на кой ляд было делать такие линейные локации? Весь цимес предыдущих биошоков заключался в возможности лазить по большим уровням, в поисках дневников, лута и прочих интересностей. В Инфините какбэ тоже можно собирать дневнини с лутом, да вот только они валяются в лучшем случае за углом. Если опустить всю эту писанину, я хочу сказать, что подпивасный шутерок на вечерок - не то, что ждешь от игры с "Bioshock" в названии. И да, если что, всё написанное касается лишь оригинальной игры, а не длц.

A game with an interesting beginning, beautiful graphics, artstyle, and fun shooting gameplay, but why would I not recommend it? Because of the latter portion of the story.

The beginning gave you questions, as it should, which are answered later on, but you're introduced to Columbia in a fantastic way. You get to see absolutely everything it possibly has as you float calmly in the air with the strength of the sun illuminating everything on your path. Several people are seen interacting with the environment, and sometimes each other.

After your first traveling to a different temporal tangent, the story just...dies. You feel alone in an empty world, and there's absolutely no positivity. All that happens afterwards is 'Chop den shoot. Shoot den chop!' with sporadic interactions with new characters in a literal tornado of death Columbia is floating in.

Revolutionaries have completely taken over by the first travel, and you don't see the local law enforcement anymore somehow. It would be understandable if they take over near the end, but seeing no exchange between the two factions kills a lot of potential immersion, story telling, and fun one could get from the story.

Looking back at the trailers for the game, the story looked far more interesting and the world more alive. Instead, we have a dried husk with parasites writhing about it that we need to shoot off.

[b]SPOILERS AHEAD[/b]

As for the ending, it's the stupidest and most paradoxical aspect of the game. I get what the storytellers were going for, but it doesn't work. I liked the idea that Comstock is just an alternate version of Booker, which made me intrigued that we had to kill another version of ourselves to save our daughter which that version pined for for so long.

And then they shoot themselves in the head. Throughout the game you'll have constant access to temporal rifts and see the effects of Elizabeth's unexplained powers bleeding into reality because potato. This can be seen through things like dead people seeing a bleeding effect from other realities bringing them back to life but trapping them in a state of flux because they can't tell which timeline is which.

This is done INCORRECTLY the VERY FIRST time it happens, because the people you kill before the first travel somehow affect those who were still alive in the new tangent. They're alive. They'd be more than aware that they weren't killed. It can be argued, but the effects would not last at all because of what they're saying in their flux delirium.

The ending straight out kills Booker in the most annoying paradox always used by any form of media entertainment. Because there's an anchor point in Booker's time that created Comstock and him, the 'logical' thing is to kill him at that point, killing Comstock. You then awaken, with no explanation, back in your Noir detective office and open the door to see if your child is there, and it leaves on a cliffhanger. The cliffhanger I liked. The rest of that aspect I didn't.

It's not by killing that Dewitt by bringing him to the past that you're destroying Comstock. The whole story functions on the broken and paradoxical principle of 'Erasing timelines'. That's not how time works. That would create a looping paradox.

So while the rest of the game is great, the latter portion is not. It's dead, empty, and the only amusing parts was when the Lutece twins appeared.

В случае с "Bioshock: Infinity" сложно выделить какую-то одну вещь, которая больше всего пришлась по душе, так как за что бы не взялся, все радует душу. Интересная и неглупая история. Язвительный и грубый герой, который не так прост, как хочет показаться на первый взгляд. Умная и решительная героиня, которая вопреки ожиданиям не является девушкой, которую нужно спасать, а наоборот - она сама вас спасет, в горячке боя, найдя аптечку, оружие, а то и что покруче... не буду портить впечатление, сами все увидите. Отличная боевая система, сочетающая стрельбу с использованием магии, которая здесь зовется энергетиками, благодаря чему чувствуешь себя сверхчеловеком, что с радостью раздает зуботочины всем мимо проходящим. Нет, конечно же, игра спуску не даст и стоит зазеваться, как в вас понаделают лишних дырок, но не создается чувства, будто враги жульничают. Аптечек, солей (Аналог маны) и оружия на уровне в достатке, так что если тебя и убивают, то виновным оказываешься ты сам, а не во-о-он тот паропанковский терминатор с физиономией Джорджа Вашингтона, и это радует. Как радует и общая визуальная составляющая и порой ловишь себя на мысли, что вот уже пять минут разглядываешь очередную статую Пророка. 

Итог? Отличная игра, которая является усладой для глаз, проверкой ваших моторных навыков, а также пищей для ума. Подобных игр не так уж много, а потому, если вы еще не играли в "Bioshock: Infinity", то самое время это исправить.

Well, only took about 5 years to get around to playing it, but it was worth it.

Possible spoilers follow.  I don't think they are.  I think they're more 'vague hints that you'll only recognize in context after you've played through them yourself', but maybe I'm not as vague as I think I am.  Or maybe you're a great guesser.  I don't know you.

First, just to get it out of the way, the graphics are good with touches of greatness.  The cover songs you'd find playing sometimes threw me off due to the timeline, but then about 80% of the way in, it was explained.  Control is fluid, the skylines are awesome (though targeting a landing can be hard, since you'll slide a bit when you hit the ground).

The vigors are so-so.  I had a couple that I preferred, based on context, and pretty much never used the rest.  The respawning mechanic works well, but I do wish that there was a "respawn or reload" option.

I assume if you get lucky with loot, and you find every source of funds, you might be able to purchase all upgrades before the endgame, but it's pretty much a moot point - like I said, you're unlikely to actively make use of every vigor regularly, and the limitation of being unable to carry more than 2 weapons means that you'll probably just stick with a few favorites there, too.

Elizabeth is amazing, by the way, she's the opposite of an escort mission - she can handle herself and will get you out of trouble a lot of the time.  Not to mention that she's just a great character - when Fink started with his 'job offer' over the phone in the elevator, her expression was the perfect mix of "what the hell?" and "is this guy serious?"

I found the generosity of lockpicks in late game a little weird.  When the mechanic is first introduced, you'll be struggling to find one or two more to get past this or that door, or get into a safe.  By the end of the game you'll have more than you can carry and precious few locks that require them - yet they're still found all over the place.  It gave me the expectation that I was going to find a lot more loot hidden around, and it never happened.  Or I missed it.  One of the two.

Anyway, that's the gameplay.  All in all, solid.  Definitely fun to play.  Now the story:

FREAKING INCREDIBLE.

It's like the anti-Far-Cry-5.  There are some lingering bits that I still wonder about - that I won't burden you with here - but for the most part, it makes for an amazing story with a gut-punch of an ending that would have been hard to make more perfect.  I expected the endgame story to revolve more around Elizabeth, but she's too quick on the uptake for that.  She's figured out her story about 2 minutes in, if not instantly.  The rest is her revealing Booker's and leading him to make his own decision and then letting it play out.

Credit to the writers, here, too.  One of the problems with a game that has such a linear story, but puts you in a first-person perspective is the fact that at some point, the character has to take actions the player doesn't want.  They call attention to this, point out why these things have to happen, why you have no choice.  You want to do it differently, Booker wants to do it differently, but there's simply no other option.

By the time Booker has the biggest choice of all, they've lead you - as the player - into being completely on-board, so the consequences are a shock, but you feel the same resignation that Booker does.  It has to happen this way.

This is a game I'll be thinking on for a while, (hopefully) enjoying the DLC, and maybe replaying a time or two.

Oh - if I must think of something about which to caution you, then let me offer this - the pace of the early and mid game is so swift, that by the time you feel that you're nearing the ending, even with exploration, you may be thinking you have an hour - maybe two.  If you explore everything, it's closer to 4 or 5.  Do not try to wrap up before bed if you work the next day.  Just saying.

Otherwise, AMAZING.

Let me get this out of the way - i hated the first two installments of Bioshock franchise. I didn't play them when they came out, i only played them for the first time last week, when i got Bioshock Collection on sale. I didn't have my nostalgia goggles on when playing, and perhaps that is why i see the first two Bioshocks for what they really are - games where gameplay is sacrificed for story; games which desperately try not to be dreaded "generic FPS", only to become an FPS where no attention was paid to fluidity and intuitiveness of gameplay. But hey, story!!!11!

Let me also state that art style of both first two Bioshocks and Bioshock Infinite do not appeal to me. I mean, the graphics are great and all, but i'm just more of a futuristic Tron-esque sci-fi than steampunk/retrofuturism kind of person, and this kind of art style does not touch my heart in any way, shape or form.

The plot is... well, non-sensical. It made good amount of sense up until last few minutes of the game, and then it all suddenly went downhill. The ending is not really a "plot twist" as much as it's a Guy Ritchie's "Revolver" kind of ending, where the writers attempted to say something profound, but ended up saying something incoherent. I'd probably get it if go and read some fan wiki, but honestly, if i have to do that, you've already failed at story telling. Cue the "hurr durr go play call of duty".

All of that said, is it a good game? Yes, it is. I thoroughly enjoyed my playthrough. In fact, after dreading through the first Bioshock and rage-quitting the second, i was positively shocked that i not only did not [i]dread[/i] playing Infinite, i actually [i]positively enjoyed[/i] playing it. Plot or not plot, graphics or not graphics, at the end of the day, gameplay is king. And unlike the first two Bioshocks, this game delivers. The Vigors (plasmids in Bioshock 1-speak) are actually useful. You don't run out of ammo so often. The weapons actually kill your enemies. It's more or less always clear what you have to do and how to kill your way through the game.

So, yeah. Even if you don't like steampunk/retrofuturism (or, in this case, [i]very retro[/i]-futurism, as the game is set in 1910's), you owe it to yourself to play this game. It's very good. Play it, especially if, like me, you thought that first two Bioshocks sucked.
Hell of a story... When will there be a movie?! Sequel?! C'mon continue!
